snippet: The anti-inflammatory drug Toradol has in recent years become a go-to elixir for baseball and football players, but little is known about the lasting implications, if any, for athletes.
abstract: Pregame use of the injectable anti-inflammatory drug Toradol has become common among baseball and football players, even as medical experts warn that its long-term effects are poorly understood; December 2011 lawsuit filed by a dozen retired NFL players alleges that indiscriminate use of Toradol has lead to exacerbated injuries.

byline.original: By KEN BELSON and MARY PILON
byline.contributor: Barry Meier and Andrew Keh contributed reporting, Pat Borzi contributed from Minneapolis, Zach Berman from Philadelphia and Ben Strauss from Chicago.

lead_paragraph: The anti-inflammatory drug Toradol has in recent years become a go-to elixir for baseball and football players, but little is known about the lasting implications, if any, for athletes.

headline.seo: Use of Painkiller Toradol Before Games Raises Concerns
headline.main: Concern Raised Over Painkiller’s Use in Sports
headline.print_headline: Concern Raised Over Painkiller’s Use in Sports
